Comments_List: I learned a quick refresher on fluid mechanics/partial differential equations. Also, I learned about surface gravity waves, rossby waves, internal flows, and convection.
How to solve a wide range of complex fluid mechanics and geophysical fluid dynamics problems
I learned a lot about fluid mechanics and how this applies to geophysical processes. I also learned a lot about specific problems and how to work through them mathematically.

I developed a knowledge of gravity currents and viscid flow, surface waves and perturbation, and convention with and without rotation. I used vector notation, the E-D rule, and conservation of mass and energy to derive equations for the scenarios above.

I learned a bunch of fluid mechanics. How to use tensor notation, how to manipulate governing equations and apply boundary conditions based on different situations to arrive at formulas that describe things like viscous flow, gravity currents and cavity flow, inviscid (i.e. non-viscous) flow like acoustic waves, gravity waves, and flows in a rotating system like geostrophic flow...
This is how Dave Bercovici taught the course, I hear it is different when ML Timmermans teaches it. Dave is a baller though so it's cool
We were pressed for time in the course, and its slow to start up. If MENG 361 fluid mechanics was a prerequisite, we could have moved faster.

I think this course does a good job of both introducing students to fluid mechanics and walking them through some important geological fluid dynamics problems. It would have been nice to have one more general lecture giving an overview of different types of problems and how these methods are used by researchers today, but otherwise the class was very clear and well taught.

I doubt this course will be taught by Dave again in the foreseeable future, so please remember that many of these points only apply to this years course, as Dave taught it.

Strengths:
The small size the Geophysical designation grants let Professor B tailor the material to students interests. Quite a few lectures began with Ive got few different concepts we could cover  heres what they are  what should we cover first? 
Overall, a good introduction to fluid dynamics, even if we never got to magneto-hydrodynamics
Clear lectures (see the question below for more on Professor Bercovici)
Interesting, challenging-but-reasonable problem sets

Weaknesses:
Some steps in lecture derivations could be a bit hand-wavey or could bear to be covered in more depth.
In a course with so much material, the absence of any midterms or final has upsides (respect for time) and downsides (possibly, slightly less comprehension/knowledge synthesis)

The class is good because you start from the beginning with everything and theoretically it all makes sense, after a whole semester of deriving different equations for different types of flow, you've done some of the basic techniques so many times that you know it well. However, the course covers a lot and moves really fast, and if you're not following with whatever happened last class by the time the next one starts, you can easily get lost or feel like you don't know why whatever the prof is doing on the board is happening. The notes are really clear though, so if you copy everything down and ask the TA in between classes, you should be fine.

Yes; it was a very fun class and Bercovici is a really great instructor. He keeps the material within class interests and explains it at a fairly decent level. The homework reflects the material, and the TA was also very intelligent in his knowledge regarding GFD.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in GFD. It is more comprehensive, better taught and more interesting than engineering fluid mechanics classes, so I would strongly recommend to someone who is choosing between MENG 361 and GFD.
If they are interested in fluid dynamics and earth systems and enjoy math, I would recommend this course to another student.

I would recommend this course to another student.

I had never taken a class in Fluid Dynamics before, and took this course at the behest of my advisor, Mark Brandon, who thought it would be a good-if-challenging introduction to fluid mechanics. In this respect, he was absolutely right. 

I feel pretty far from mastering most of these concepts and derivations, but I know that Ive seen and worked with them. I feel that my time in the course was well worth it.

I mean yea, if you're going to do anything related to the math behind geophysical flows (i.e. any kind of flow out in the physical world), this class is a must. It's a bit of a doozy though so be ready, and start the psets early, do them w friends, go to office hours, you know the drill...
